title: RS20702
content: The Water Resources Development Act of 2000 authorized federal agencies to participate in Everglades restoration projects under the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan. The Everglades is crucial to the South Florida ecosystem, which includes national wildlife refuges, national park units, a large population, and agricultural economy. Changes in water quantity, quality, and distribution since the 1950s have significantly impacted the region's ecology. The Everglades in South Florida, home to national wildlife refuges and a large population, has experienced significant changes in water quantity and quality since the 1950s. Current water shortages during the dry season cannot meet the needs of both natural systems and urban/agricultural demand, with more frequent shortages expected in the future. During the dry season, South Florida faces water shortages due to lower rainfall, impacting both natural systems and urban/agricultural demand.
